science.headline: How Animals Build a Sense of Direction
science.teaser: Researchers recorded the neurons that shape directional navigation as bats explored a remote island off the coast of Tanzania. The post How Animals Build a Sense of Direction first appeared on Quanta Magazine
science.tldr: Undermines long-held theories on animal navigation and spatial awareness

science.headline: How Being a Good Dad Makes for Healthier Children
science.teaser: Paternal warmth before the age of 1 can set the tone for the family and influence physical health years later The post How Being a Good Dad Makes for Healthier Children appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Establishes a foundation for physical health through paternal warmth

science.headline: Heartworms Might Be Much More Ancient Than We Thought
science.teaser: Understanding their intricate past could be key to future treatments for pups The post Heartworms Might Be Much More Ancient Than We Thought appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Reveals the origins of heartworms, potentially leading to new treatments

science.headline: Construction of complex and diverse DNA sequences using DNA three-way junctions
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10006-0 Sidewinder enables high-fidelity DNA assembly by separating the information that guides assembly from the final assembled sequence.
science.tldr: Identifies a new method for assembling complex DNA sequences

science.headline: Temporal tissue dynamics from a spatial snapshot
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09876-1 One-shot tissue dynamics reconstruction can infer changes in tissue composition over time, from single-time-point spatial proteomics of human cancers.
science.tldr: Reconstructing tissue dynamics provides crucial insight into cellular behavior and evolution

science.headline: Detailed View of Solar Flare Birth Caught for the First Time
science.teaser: They start small and end huge The post Detailed View of Solar Flare Birth Caught for the First Time appeared first on Nautilus .
science.tldr: Captures the first detailed view of solar flare birth in history

science.headline: Rock art from at least 67,800 years ago in Sulawesi
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09968-y A hand stencil painted on a cave wall on a small island off the coast of Sulawesi more than 67,800 years ago suggests a very early occupation of Wallacea.
science.tldr: Recognizes oldest known human artistic expression outside Africa

science.headline: Core–envelope miscibility in sub-Neptunes and super-Earths
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09970-4 First-principles molecular dynamics driven by density functional theory is used to show that silicate and hydrogen are completely miscible over a wide range of plausible core–envelope pressure–temperature conditions.
science.tldr: Reveals key details about composition and stability of sub-Neptunes planets

science.headline: Symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09883-2 The symmetry, microscopy and spectroscopy signatures of altermagnetism are reviewed, and compared with traditional ferromagnetism and Néel antiferromagnetism, and magnetic phases with symmetry-protected compensated non-colline
science.tldr: Reveals unexpected properties of altermagnetism through novel symmetry observations

science.headline: Pyramidal neurons proportionately alter cortical interneuron subtypes
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09996-8 Pyramidal neuron-driven mechanisms actively promote the survival and terminal differentiation of their associated interneuron subtypes.
science.tldr: Promotes new understanding of cortical circuitry and neuronal interactions

science.headline: Extreme barocaloric effect at dissolution
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10013-1 An extreme barocaloric effect in NH4SCN aqueous solutions is enabled by pressure-induced dissolution and precipitation, but without using a separate heat-transfer liquid.
science.tldr: Reveals a new mechanism for barocaloric effects in aqueous solutions

science.headline: Four camera-type eyes in the earliest vertebrates from the Cambrian Period
science.teaser: Nature, Published online: 21 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09966-0 Early vertebrates, particularly myllokunmingids, possessed four camera-type eyes (a pair of lateral eyes and pineal and parapineal organs), which indicates that these structures functioned in image formation, in support of the
science.tldr: Reveals a new understanding of early vertebrate vision and sensory capabilities

philosophy.headline: The Emergence of Order in All (Large) Things
philosophy.teaser: by Jonathan Kujawa One common theory of intelligence is that it is an emergent phenomenon. One-on-one, termites aren’t exactly geniuses. But get enough of them together, and they build incredibly elaborate communities that can be 30 meters across with sophisticated ventilation systems to control hea
philosophy.tldr: Challenges our understanding of intelligence with simple yet complex social structures

philosophy.headline: New Business School Centers Ethics in Its Curriculum and Marketing
philosophy.teaser: Georgetown University’s McDonough School of Business has revamped its MBA curriculum and has made ethics a focal point of its first-year curriculum. A press release about the changes states that As part of the opening term, students will kick off their MBA experience with a course focused on ethical
philosophy.tldr: Emphasizes the importance of ethics in business education and practice

philosophy.headline: Stevenson’s Treasure
philosophy.teaser: Robert Louis Stevenson (1850–94) belongs at the head of a select company of writers renowned in their day who are no longer taken seriously, or for that matter read much, by most adults... The post Stevenson’s Treasure appeared first on First Things .
philosophy.tldr: Revises our understanding by shedding light on Stevenson's literary legacy

philosophy.headline: Fact-Checking the New Yorker
philosophy.teaser: Back in the day, when the New Yorker set the standard for literary elegance among serious American journals, writers were driven to distraction by the fanatical fact-checking characteristic of... The post Fact-Checking the New Yorker appeared first on First Things .
philosophy.tldr: Challenges the notion that The New Yorker remains the standard for literary elegance

philosophy.headline: Bas van Fraassen Wins Schock Prize
philosophy.teaser: Bastiaan “Bas” van Fraassen, professor emeritus of philosophy at Princeton University, has been awarded the 2026 Rolf Schock Prize in Logic and Philosophy. The Schock Prize in Logic and Philosophy is bestowed by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (KVA). Winners each receive 600,000 Swedish kronor
philosophy.tldr: Awarding Bas van Fraassen recognizes his significant contributions

society.headline: The Folly of Fatalism in Gaza
society.teaser: To broker peace, America should draw on its past successes in the Middle East.

society.tldr: Highlights essential reads for readers seeking meaningful literary and intellectual experiences

society.headline: Why Trump Sides With Putin

society.headline: South Korea Can Stand Up to China
society.teaser: With its allies, Seoul has enough leverage to push back.
society.tldr: Challenges China's growing influence in East Asia are crucial for Korea

society.headline: If You Read This You Are Gay
society.teaser: For the terminally online, politics à la carte.

society.headline: 2. Religious and spiritual beliefs in Latin America

society.headline: Why Albums Drop and Movies Launch
society.teaser: The ephemeral nature of contemporary music consumption has made it much harder to elevate an album—even a very good one—into the category of an event.

She’s too dressed up: wearing tights with seams up the back, a low-cut dress and heels that will ensure eyes follow us into every room. I do the opposite: I […] The post A Genius Can Alway
